            TRUST FUND,TF035805-ZIMBABWE - FAMILY HEALTH II,TF033821-ZIMBABWE - HEALTH,TF020631-FAMILY HEALTH/II,TF022045-2ND FAMILY HEALTH PROJECT IN ZIMBABWE,TF020600-FINNISH GENERAL CONSULTANT
            TRUST FUND,TF023155-SECOND FAMILY HEALTH

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Family Health Project was
            marginally successful with an uncertain sustainability.
            Lessons learned include: a) using agreed report formats
            facilitates the review process, and reduces the different
            reports which have to be prepared; b) reviews that involve
            all partners result in improved results; c) close
            collaboration with the Bank's macro-economists is
            important to seeking solutions to the impact that the
            macro-economic policies might have on objective attainment;
            c) reliance on parallel financing in the absence of agreed
            development objectives makes objective attainment uncertain;
            d) utilizing a sector investment program during times of
            economic uncertainty would provide flexibility and
            facilitate the Bank's ability to respond to changing
            circumstances in-country and to client's needs; f)
            involving users and appropriate expertise at the planning
            and construction stage results in buildings that meet
            functional needs and are built within budget; g) staggering
            construction activities across the life of the project would
            ease high peak loads at critical stages of construction, as
            well as the workload of staff supervising, valuing and
            making payments, and allow curtailment of construction if
            deemed prudent; and h) having a commissioning system in
            place and staff adequately trained in its use greatly
            reduces the potential complications in the delivery of
            health facility equipment.
